content.description: A difficult start leads to some sustained technical climbing up the seam. One more hard sequence toward the top gets you to the anchors. This gets 12c in the most recent CCC guidebook by Kevin Capps.
content.location:
It is located on a clean panel 30 feet left of

City of the Dead

. This route follows a nice seam for 5 bolts then finishes up and right to an anchor shared with

Back From the Dead

.

content.description:
This route surprisingly climbs better than it initially looks. Begin the climb 30 feet right of

Spinal Tap

.

Please keep in mind a 70m rope will

NOT

reach the ground from the upper anchor. Taller folks might find this route a bit easier, 5.9-5.9+. Also note, there may still be some loose rock/dirt (I did however spend quite a few hours cleaning the route).

Pitch 1 – 5. 8 –

Climb up a large boulder, and clip the somewhat high first bolt (easy 5th). Climb on moderate terrain to a small roof which leads to an excellent belay ledge,

11 bolts + a 2 bolt anchor, ~85 feet.

Pitch 2 – 5.10a –

From the ledge, ascend a short overhang (crux) which leads to another, easier overhang. The second pitch anchor is located on another decent ledge,

6 bolts + a 2 bolt anchor, ~45 feet.

Rappel the route.

I thought this was the most interesting and fun route in the cluster of 5.10 routes (most a little soft for the grade) left-center at Graveyard.

A few wonky lieback, stem, and face moves in a right-facing corner lead to a classic lieback section.

Rest up at the ledge just after halfway before tackling the gym-like headwall.

I thought the crux was at the top of the headwall near the last clip. Slightly runout but easy scrambling leads to the anchors (quicklinks and chains).
content.protection: 10 bolts to chains. There are two 2-bolt anchors up top - use the higher one on left with some easier and runout scrambling to get to it.
content.location: This is the rightmost of the cluster of 5.10s at the top of the current social trail. This is just left of a fairly smooth face with obviously harder lines on it and just right of a short climb punctuated by a roof.

content.description:
Climb over a couple of bulges to reach the roof and the start of a small, right-facing corner. Make a couple of fun moves getting established and moving out to a jug below the lip. Find the holds over the lip (even if you can't see them!). Pull up, and clip the anchors.

This route is still evolving, with several loose holds.

I enjoyed the movement in the corner and hope it all stays together, but be careful till it cleans up.
content.location:
The left side of the Graveyard features a short roof. This route climbs the roof via a short, right-facing corner/groove. Begin just a few feet left of

The Reaper

.

Watch out for cactus!

content.description:
This climb goes up a crack systems right of

Ugoogoly

in a right-facing dihedral. You can start low on easy terrain or on a ledge higher up by

The Walking Dead

and

Back from the Dead

. The higher ledge start seems better. The crux seems to be at the top of the dihedral before you move left onto a big ledge below a crack which is the rest of the route. There is some loose crumbly rock on the route, but the protection is good, and the upper crack is fun.
content.protection: A standard rack to a #3 Camalot. Two #2 Camalots are nice to have. There is a two bolt chain anchor.
content.location:
This route starts to the right of

Ugoogoly

and to the left of the two higher 5.12s. The right-facing dihedral is obvious.

climbs.name: Spinal Tap
climbs.fa: Kevin Capps, Nate Moore, Michael Hauck, 2017

content.description: From the sizable ledge, climb the rightmost bolt line (easily identified as the bolt line heading right from the two bottom belay bolts) up the white face. A short section of good holds leads to a sequential, sustained headwall of crimps. Finesse the crux near the top, and then motor on easy ground to the anchor.
content.location:
Per

Daniel Kaye

: at the top right side of the crag, it's the second-rightmost bolt line from the comfortably small belay ledge with 2 black anchor bolts you probably don't need up there. Look for a bolt line that trends slightly right up a slopy-looking slightly-overhanging clean face for 6 or so visible bolts.

You get up to this ledge by following a trail with light scrambling under/along the cliff to climber's right, which eventually does a switchback or two and plops you at a small ledge with some anchor bolts. It's right of

Hellbender

(12b, which has a permadraw at a small roof about 6 clips up) and left of

Bone Daddy

(an awkward 5.9 that climbs up a broken, bulgy weakness in the cliff).

content.description:
Well, I mean, it's still climbing, right?

Easier face climbing leads to a two-move crux bulge. The bulge is a little tricky with a few different ways to do it. Surmount the bulge, and continue up easier climbing to a two bolt anchor.
content.protection: 11 bolts. This route (and most routes at the wall) could use some cleaning as it is still shedding plenty of small rocks.
content.location: Currently, it is the second leftmost route at the wall and just left of a short route with a difficult roof. The social approach trail switchbacks under it.

content.description: Begin up some jugs (some questionable rock) to a section of sustained, enjoyable climbing. Reach a ledge, and continue with another thought provoking sequence before the anchor.
content.protection:
7 (11?) bolts + anchor.

Per

Derek Young

: this shares an anchor with

Afterlife

.

Per

Kevin W

: you can easily go to the left and use the anchor for

The Reaper

, 10d, if someone is on

Afterlife

. It's just a bit higher to the left. The top is not 10d climbing. Essentially the left 3 routes share two anchors, so someone can be on

The Reaper

/Reincarnation and

Afterlife

at the same time easily.
content.location:
This route climbs the bolt line just right of a small chossy gully and is left of

Afterlife

.

content.description: Begin up a chossy gully with some bushes to the first bolt. The crux comes quickly as you climb through the second bolt at a bulge. Once you've reached the ledge, climb up a dirty dihedral to the anchor. This route needs some traffic or a good brushing to improve.
content.location:
Per

Daniel Kaye

: from the nice staging area on the left side of the cliff with all the 5.10s (basically where the approach train meets the cliff), this is the leftmost line of them. It's maybe ten feet right of the big steep roof that only has one route on it (

Tomb Raider

).

content.description:
Low Priest was bolted (and the anchor added) really just as entry pitch to Matt’s new 5.12 roof crack,

High Priest

. With that being said, it is an independent line with an anchor, so I thought I’d post it here for easy identification.

*Please tread with care/test your holds until this line has cleaned up a bit!*

Traverse into the first bolt from the left via a sloping rail until perhaps the bottom cleans up. Clip 7 bolts total on the way to the chains. Belly to the bolt line provides interesting climbing, though it’s possible to weave around a bit if those moves aren’t to your liking. The climbing is fun, though a cautious leader may find a bit of runout between some of the higher bolts.

Thanks, Matt, for giving us a new easier pitch at the Graveyard and for letting me be the first to give this a go!
content.location: It is on the middle/right side of the crag below the big, obvious roof up high and right of the clean face with the 2 5.12c climbs.

content.description: High Priest is the left of the two obvious lines on the giant roof. This line is technically an extension of “Low Priest”, which ends below the large headwall.
content.protection: 7 bolts and trad gear through the roof. A singles rack is plenty. Bring some long draws to avoid rope drag.
content.location:
It’s easy to find - it is just left of the sport climb 12a called

City of the Dead

.

climbs.name: Hellbender
climbs.fa: Kevin Capps, Michael Hauck, Nate Moore, 2017

content.description: Climb up easy ground for a few bolts to a smack down crux presenting itself halfway up the wall. Pull on bad sloping crimps, and get established on an undercling that seems to be angling the wrong way. Get a few better holds, and save up for a few more challenging moves off sloping crimps and non-existent holds to great holds below the roof. A jug haul victory romp leads to the chains.
content.location: Start on the far right side of the cliff, and follow the bolt line directly above the 2-bolt belay anchor, past a permadraw at the roof.

climbs.name: Grave Digger
climbs.fa: Kevin Capps, Nate Moore, Michael Hauck, 2017

content.description: Climb up easy ground for a long ways to the first bolt (you can also clip the first bolt of the adjacent route). Get a nice stance, and pull the devious & reachy slab boulder problem to good holds above. Climb easy ground up to the roof, rest well, and launch into the sustained, sloping crimp section above. Traverse left once the crimps run out, finishing on slightly easier climbing to the chains.
content.location:
Up the hill on the far right side of the wall, this is the leftmost of the four routes starting off the highest point on the wall  Note that if the belay area is crowded, it is possible to belay directly below this route next to the start of "

Ernest Stemingway

."

content.description: Ascend a long edge toward the western end of the area. There are positive crimps above to claw you out of the grave.

Begin up the blocky face to a small ledge. From the ledge is a tricky slab/face section which leads to somewhat easier climbing. Then decode the final "stem" sequence to the anchor.

The crux is either the slab/face or the final stem.

climbs.name: Dia de Los Muertos
climbs.fa: Kevin Capps, Nate Moore, Michael Hauck, 2017

content.description: Begin with excellent technical climbing up a left-angling seam. From a nice rest beneath the roof, fire up through an undercling into a sustained series of small edges. This has great movement all around!
content.location: This route sits in the upper right portion of the crag and is the second bolt line from the left in this group of four.

content.description: This should clean up into a fun warm-up. Start a ways left of where the trail meets the wall. Follow 7 bolts up a short face to a ledge then over a couple of bulges through a weakness to an anchor with Climb Tech hooks.
content.location: This is the furthest route to the left with black hangers.

content.description: This route is one of the longer routes at the crag with the crux at the top. Begin up the route on some technical face which then turns into two sections of thoughtful slab. Take a rest before the final hand crack roof. Crank through the roof, and fire up some hidden jugs to the anchor.
content.location:
It is left of

Ernest Stemmingway

.

content.description: The bulb right off the bat is how the route was named. It has great texture and clean rock. There are obvious holds straight up until the very end and good foot holds directly beneath.

Bone Daddy offers fun climbing on the gently overhanging face about 10 feet right of

Spinal Tap

. It can be tricky to figure out. If it feels hard, then you might be missing something.

The rock around the first bolt is still cleaning up, so be mindful.
content.protection: 6 bolts to an anchor with Mussy hooks..
content.location:
It is the first route to the right of

Spinal Tap

and the rightmost bolted route on this section of wall.

content.description:
This route starts similarly to

The Walking Dead

but traverses right up the face on small/slopey holds. Figure out your beta to make the tough traverse to gain a decent hold, then finish up and left on easier climbing to the anchors shared with

The Walking Dead

.
content.location:
This is 30 feet left of the overhanging crack,

City of the Dead

.

content.description: Start up some jugs to clip the first bolt. Climb carefully to the very high second bolt; don't blow it or you'll deck from 20 feet up! Face climbing leads to a ledge, and once above the ledge, enjoyable, technical climbing guides you to the anchor.
content.location:
Per

Derek Young

: this shares the anchor with

Reincarnation

.
